data.title: Angela Fordice Jordan signs WE END IN JOY: MEMOIRS OF A FIRST DAUGHTER
data.text:
Angela Jordan enjoyed a comfortable and quiet life in Vicksburg, the

small southern town in which she was reared. She was a

thirty-five-year-old mother of three daughters, and a woman with a

politically liberal bent, when, against all history's odds,

Mississippians elected her conservative Republican father, Kirk Fordice,

governor in 1991.

Suddenly fate threw the whole Fordice

family into the glaring lights of public life. They made headlines,

enlivened the 6 o'clock television news, and provided fodder for every

dinner table conversation and robust political speculation around the

Southeast. As the Governor and First Lady Fordices' longstanding

marriage dissolved slowly and publicly over two terms in office,

everyone with a newspaper subscription or a cable connection watched the

trainwreck and high-profile betrayals.
